good UX requires giving the user what they expect, which means that if they intend to share something, it needs to be shared. permission errors aren't acceptable when they can defeat the restriction by using a common but slightly less convenient option for sharing that thing. (so i think references to private things should include or at least have the option of including the actual content regardless of permissions, although i realize that caching the content correctly probably creates some challenges)

👋 I'm back to life - we had an issue where in addition to the performance issues with initial group join a bug was making joining the group impossible. The team has fixed this (release is going out now with the fix) and with the additional trim work, initial group join/channel history load time has gone from 9 minutes to around 30 seconds.
We're also working hard on the faster group join refactor work (which will fix this problem among others without needing to trim history). I'll share progress as we get close to having that in place.
If your friends had issues joining this group, they should be able to get in once that group update lands for them (either already for in a couple minutes, hash: tm07o).

it's easy to criticize existing network tech because there have been a ton of awful decisions, but this computer that was made before the web existed is able to use a network card that implements the original 10Mb ethernet protocol from 1980 to connect to a gigabit router from 2013 and an OS and browser from 1996 to access websites being served by modern servers in 2015
It's genuinely remarkable, and (from at least one of my perspectives) indicative of the value of stable protocols and well-designed software.

This is why I'm not bullish on the idea of nostr relays as businesses. There will be a handful but it's a race to the bottom to provide the cheapest access to the least possible data. Bespoke, high cost relays will be rare even in a success case. Urbit stars are the inverse. They're not just data repos but can provide any number of services from escrow to streaming to site hosting. Much more versatile.

I won't get into whether this is a good idea because that doesn't matter. The relevant question is what technology is best for doing this and at this point it doesn't matter functionally. This is a simple data structure that just needs to be broadcast and have some local filtering on what data from whom is available to the user. Could use anything for it. The thing that I think makes Urbit better than the alternatives is that on Urbit the user owns and controls the data. Eventually, nostr relays are going to prune their data and delete anything someone isn't paying for. People will lose data. On Urbit, that's impossible.

I think both types of names have different uses. Urbit IDs are like phone numbers where a small percentage are nice but most are random and hard to remember. People just live with their random phone number and don't really care. DNS, whether centralized or not, has significant value because the names are meaningful. You can find out your friend's phone number easily by asking them, but imagine if you saw a bus ad for an interesting product and could only access the company's website using a random number

with Namecoin you can name your page anything[dot]anything at all, have a human readable username that can not be taken away from you AND give relays the ability to do the same, so that users can easily find their curated content.

I can summarize the thinking about it:

- Small Talk was only useful for people already deep into urbit with existing groups and channels, it's a power user accessory for people that are primarily desktop users (or at least started there to set things up) and pretty useless for a new user or anyone that hasn't spent a lot of time with desktop urbit.

- It's strategically critical that a new user can download our app, onboard into urbit, and get the full functionality of groups right from the app, most users are mobile first or mobile only. The app can't just be an accessory to the desktop.

- In theory this could be done with native apps across the platforms, but we have limited resources and have to spend them wisely, mobile groups lets us use the investments we're making to make the web ui high quality and then deliver that to both mobile platforms simultaneously. This let's us focus on one thing (excellent mobile groups app experience) and ship improvements everywhere. Trying to make a native ios app, native android app, and desktop web app isn't viable for us right now.

Vision Pro was such a flex; they're so much better at this than everyone else, but it is remarkable that so much of our highest-quality brainpower was so focussed to produce a personal entertainment system whose first generation will serve as a novelty for one or two million people.
I have talented friends at apple - don't really agree with the premise, and the Apple Silicon stuff is so good that it's forcing non-apple dev toolchains to adapt.

Vision Pro success is hard to know, but it matches all of their other big products (later entry into an immature field with mediocre products and winning the entire field: mp3 players, smart phones, smart watch, etc.) and I think it's a viable bet on a future platform/UX.

Their hardware is fairly priced relative to performance/quality and polish imo. The stuff they suck at is siri which I think is a concern given the importance of the AI shift, but I'd guess they're hacking on a big change there in secret (I think they suck at it in part due to their position on privacy).

Repeating a thread here, but when I entered this industry getting into Apple was like ascending. Now I don’t know anyone skilled who wants to go there and everyone good I know who was there has left with little good to say. The hardware is excellent but not sufficient for the price compared to the competition. The M1 is an achievement but sucks in non-Apple dev toolchains. The Vision Pro will probably be a boondoggle (I worked in VR for 3 years during peak hype). I just don’t believe they’ve solved the headset issues.I really struggle to understand any positive association with their work for the last few years outside of students and designers/artists.

Ok I quit

I think Apple's strategic approach is a lot more plausible than meta's to get adoption. The bet is it can be a better productivity device for an individual. This doesn't require all your friends to also have headsets in order to get any value like it does with social (and single player games without social are a smaller niche). If Apple can provide a better UX for regular stuff for a single person then it can grow through that market and iterate on the hardware.

Whether their first gen hardware is good enough for this as a v0 remains unknown, but using your visual field for UX seems clearly superior to (often small) glass displays if they can pull it off. Eye tracking for interaction is also as close as you can get to telepathic input imo. My bet is if apple is entering the market it's because they feel their hardware meets this quality bar (and I think nothing else in the market has come close yet).
